newsitem.title: UK: London gold firm in Europe after Easter holiday.
newsitem.headline: London gold firm in Europe after Easter holiday.

text.p: Gold started the post-Easter week on a firmer footing on Tuesday, but the white metals were treading on shakier territory.
Dealers said sharp losses on Wall Street on Thursday and Monday had helped to attract investors to gold, buoying prices.
Bullion fixed at $349.85 an ounce compared to $348.15 last Thursday before the London market closed for a four-day holiday.
But silver, platinum and palladium lost ground amid concerns about industrial demand in the aftermath of last week's hike in U.S. interest rates, dealers said.
"That seems a likely scenario. It was a bit of a surprise this morning to see gold up and silver down," a dealer said.
Gold edged under the psychological $350 an ounce level in early Europe but dealers said it was well supported just below.
"The $350 level may have been too high for gold. I'd guess $348-$351 will be the range for gold until New York opens later, at which time the range will widen considerably," a dealer said.

The market was shrugging off fresh news regarding Bre-X Mineral Ltd.'s controversial Busang gold deposit, analysts said. Announcements last week that the deposit may not be as rich as previously thought had shaved about $1.00 off the price of gold.

"The problems of Bre-X/Busang are not an issue for the bullion market, as any mine start-up only starts to have an impact until either a gold loan is raised or future production hedged," brokers GNI said in a report.
Silver, which tumbled amid fund selling in New York markets on Monday, was still hovering just above the psychological $5.00 an ounce level in early European trading.

It was last indicated at $5.03/$5.05, a decline of nine cents from Thursday's London close. For the time being the $5.00 level should provide support but further weakness could target the $4.80 support level dating from mid-February, dealers said.
Platinum was similarly weaker although the market was very quiet, dealers said.
It was fixed at $369.50 an ounce in the morning, compared to $373.50 on Thursday afternoon, in the lowest fixing in five weeks.
Palladium also edged lower to $145.25/$146.25, down $1.25 since Thursday's finish. --Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
